For an engine builder, there is far too much attacking inbuilt in the cards. It's crazy to be that, in a game where you are working together to terraform mars and make it habitable, a core mechanic is stealing and destroying resources others have in order to prevent them from executing their engine.

Most of the cards feel very basic in terms of the effect they have. Much of the time the decision just feels like taking the best card. There is some variety at different points of the game, but there is so much disparity between what is good and what isn't. It feels terrible to have a draw where you are do not get great cards compared to other players who get amazing cards.

I see why people like this game. The requirements on cards forcing you to think about how you terraform and build on the planet, and the end point objectives being at the mercy of players are both great mechanics that makes the game strategic and replayable. For me, the attacky nature and the variance of card quality is not worth it. Sure, drafting in each round fixes this issue somewhat, but at the cost of adding too much time to the play time of the game. Compare this to Agricola, where card quality varies, and the draft fixes things completely, allowing for completely different synergies between cards.

It's worth reiterating that the components of this game I like in isolation. I like attacking other players to gain advantage when it is executed well (Root, Arcs), unlike in this game where attacking is mainly incidental and can punish you for no reason. I like engine building when you get to really specialize your engine, both in cases where others can block your strategy (Agricola) or in cases where there isn't as much interaction between players (Creature Caravan, Arc Nova, Slay the Spire). I also like goals that are determined by the players (Arc Nova, Arcs). When you add all of this up, the sum is a game that makes me wish that I was playing literally anything else, but mainly a game that makes me wish that I was playing something that was way better in terms of how it feels/plays.

Out of the famous trio of this, Ark Nova and Wingspan this one is the second worst for me. At least here there is a central board with some slight blocking and milestones to get where you see the other players a bit more, as compared to Ark Nova. Still, the huge draw deck that will take a lot of sessions to get some knowledge of and the enormous pile of cards with icons and abilities that each player amasses is strongly present in this game. I watched a game in long progress recently and was sorely tempted to ask a player to look away from the table and tell me if they really knew what kind of cards their opponents were having. So I ask the question here, and if the answer is yes, well hats off and you can call me stupid I guess. But I find it cluttered and unmanageable, and more importantly, yes, I do feel it doesn’t affect me or my game play decisions that much.
Finally, the frozen Mars water on the cake are the absolutely horrible components. If the flimsy player boards are touched in the slightest, there is a big chance the cubes move around, which is of course a big issue for the ones tracking production. Even if you like the game, you cannot convince me this is not an issue (and no, I won’t accept deluxe boards or home made stuff as an answer; this review is about the game as it is sold in the box).

I’m honestly baffled by the hype surrounding Terraforming Mars. Sure, it’s popular, but the fact that it’s ranked 4th (at this time) in the world? That just blows my mind. Don’t get me wrong, I’m not knocking anyone who enjoys it—but let’s be real, compared to the top games out there today, it just doesn’t hold up. The game is loved by people who claim to dislike randomness, yet it’s one of the most random experiences I’ve ever had at the table.

The whole premise of the game—competing as corporations to terraform Mars by raising the temperature, increasing oxygen levels, and creating oceans—sounds fascinating on paper. You’re balancing resource management, playing unique project cards, and competing for the best spots on the board. The idea of gradually transforming the planet and vying for milestones and awards should create a tense, engaging experience. But in practice? It falls flat for me.

The late game, in particular, feels like it plays itself. You’re left making obvious, point-based decisions that lack any real excitement or strategic depth. It’s a grind, and not the kind that leaves you feeling satisfied when you finally reach the end. After just a few plays, I knew this one wasn’t for me. If someone suggests Terraforming Mars on game night, I’d honestly rather sit out and do something else. The game just doesn’t live up to the massive hype it’s built around it.

Update 03/02/2017: I'm downrating the game from 9 to 6. The game is very much take-that with 2 players, a little bit too much for my taste, especially if you count in the amount of luck in the draw. There are a couple of disjointed cards with the sole purpose of taking resources away from your opponents. In a game that is already is luck-heavy and tight on scores, this feels like lazy design. Secondly, game lasts around +2.5 hours which is just too much to see it on the table very regularly. I heard from a lot of people that drafting cards minimizes luck but it would even drag this game more than it does now.

Third, after playing for several hours, it seems like the scores are too tight in the end. In both games we played, scores of first and 2nd/3rd player differed with 1 point only which is very marginal and one take that action made the difference between a win or a loss, if you count in the high luck factor of drawing the card you would need, this is a no-go for me, especially if it lasts 2+ hours.

Component quality is also so-so - with all the lightweight cubes on the flimsy score boards, one sweep with the arms of a nearby kid would wash 3 hours of game play away in one move... luckily it didn't happen to us but I just imagine...

After all, it's a good thematic game with a lot of interesting scientific events that make sense. A game I like but not love because of the long play time, the take that cards and the tight end game scores and the flimsy production counters.

I shall start by saying that this was not what I was expecting. I hadn’t read a lot about Terraforming Mars as it looked to me like a heavy weight, dry euro game and I’m just not enjoying those at the moment. However, I was quite surprised to find that it is a light-medium weight card game that has a board in the same way that Trains is a deck builder with a board.

It is an interesting beast and seems to be a patchwork of different ideas ripped from other games; in fact, I haven’t played a game, watched a film or read a book in recent memory that so obviously and so liberally borrowed concepts and ideas from its piers. I’ll get on to that a bit more later, but first we’ll look at how it plays.

For your first game you will start with “Beginner Companies”, which is to say that they are all the same. The same starting resources, the same starting production and no special powers. You then get dealt a hand of 10 cards each from the top of an enormous deck (which would have been twice the size if you haven't taken out the ‘advanced cards’) and that’s it. Almost the entire game revolves around these cards.

The cards themselves are loosely split into 3 types: green, blue and red. Green are the most common and usually involve a onetime bonus, such as increasing the amount of one resources that you produce at the end of the round or increase the amount of that resources that you have right now. Others are a more complex, such as exchanging one unit of one resource for 2 of another, but once they have been used they are added to your tableau where the squat there until the end of the game. They have no further effects but there are icons at the top which may be relevant for scoring. Then you have the rarer blue cards, which usually give you a powerful bonus of playing them, such as a pile of resource X and then sit in your tableau and can be activated again once a round for a benefit, usually a resource cube. Lastly there are the somewhat common red cards, which usually (but not always) screw over another player by targeting their resources, ability to produce resources, or their tableau. These again are one shot and are then discarded.

You can take one or two actions on your turn, or you can pass, which means that you can no longer take part in the rest of the round. There is a list of actions that you can take, but mostly (and especially early on) you will be simply playing cards from your hands to create a tableau. Except that sometimes you won’t.

Issue 1

An issue that I picked up on early in the game is that a lot of cards have costs or requirements that have to be met, similar to Spartacus where you have to have a certain amount of influence to play. Here it may be that one of the 3 tracks has to be above or below or on a certain number. This created a peculiar situation whereby within your initial hand of 10 cards, there may only be one or two that you can play. Chances are that it won't be until later in the round and through other players affecting the game state that you will be able to play a second or third card, which could turn out to be the last. This somewhat uneven setup can create a real imbalance within the first round, whereby some players with rush of with the beginnings of fantastic engines, whereas some will just be left floundering, which leads me into my second issue.

Issue 2

Issue number 2 with the game, is that it has a bit of a runaway leader issue that also tends to reward those who are doing well and punish those who are not. For example it is not uncommon that after the first round in your first few games, one player will probably have been able to play quite a few cards from his hand, say 2 greens, 2 reds and 1 blue. As such they will have quite a substantial lead, will have knocked the other players backwards as well as getting a powerful blue card out that could be activated each round for free. At this point you will look who is in what position in terms of score; it is likely that this is exactly how the game will finish. I think the issue herein lies that your current victory point total is your base income! Meaning that the more VPs you have, the more money you have in the next round meaning you can play and more importantly, buy more cards, making your tableau and therefore your position stronger. Interestingly, the only way (apart from a few spaces on the board) that you can obtain new cards is between round where you are dealt 4 at random and can then choose to keep as many as you like, but have to pay 3 credits each. Therefore, the better you are doing, the more money you have, the more cards you can buy, the more cards you can play, the better you do. It ramps up exponentially. Furthermore, the red cards can be devastating; if you are lucky enough to be dealt them then you have to be able to afford to play them. This again means that the player with the most resources can further trample on the weak engines of those who they are trying to catch up. Then we come to the mile stones. These add a race element to the game, such as being the first to put 3 cities on the board, or the first to put down 8 vegetation tiles or build 8 buildings (represented by the brown building symbol on some of the cards in your tableau). So, if you are doing well and winning, chances are you will be the first to complete one or more of these, giving you a 5 VP bonus for each. However, to complete them you have to buy them at a cost. Now, a balancing mechanic that I have seen in a lot of games is that the first person to a powerful achievement has to pay the most, or faces an additional barrier, such as in Le Havre where in order to use the dock to build an iron ship, you also have to ‘modernise’ it by paying additional brick resources. In Terraforming Mars, it is the opposite; the first person to reach a milestone gets it for 8 and then the price goes up to 16 and then 24 for subsequent ones. Furthermore, there are 5 available but only 3 can be claimed and each only once, so it is entirely possible that you could be locked out of ever getting one. There are also awards which work in much the same way to further exasperate the issue.

Issue 3

This game can be extremely random, with the cards that you draw and that your opponents draw determining what actions can be taken over the course of the entire round. At this point I should point out the on the board are printed a selection of “Public Endeavours”, which can be used by anyone and function in a similar way to the green cards, in that you spend credit and take the action, such as putting down a vegetation tile, ocean tile etc. The issue with these, and the reason why I have neglected to mention them up until this point, is that they are just far too expensive and limited. Furthermore, as there are not cards involved, there is nothing to add into your tableau, therefore potentially denying yourself VPs at the end of the game from scoring certain icons. However, they are there and it would be remiss of me not to mention them. Back to the issue in hand. This game borrows quite heavily from Seasons (and apparently Race for the Galaxy, but I haven’t played that), but without the ability to plan out your turns. To mitigate the inherent luck in Seasons, you claim all of the cards that you will be using over the course of the game at the beginning, and then can allocated them evenly to each of the games 3 round. This way you know in advance what is going to be available and therefore you can plan accordingly.

As I mentioned earlier, in Terraforming Mars you are at the mercy of your starting hand, a massive deck of unique card, and then at the mercy of what cards you draw throughout the course of the game. There is simply no way to get around the fact that some cards are just much better than others, and some cards combine really well, but only if you get them both into your hand. This wouldn’t be such an issue with a smaller car pool, but the deck around 200 unique cards and therefore the chances of getting the 2 or 3 that you need is slim at best. Other games that rely heavily on cards get around this by having a central pool of cards that you can purchase, think Nations, Through the Ages and City of Iron, which allow you to mitigate some of the randomness and plan accordingly. Furthermore you can see if a player takes a card that could affect you negatively compose a strategy to protect yourself against the potentially negative effects of that. In Terraforming Mars you never know what card players have received or have in their hands. Furthermore, anything that they choose not to buy is discarded face down so that you have no idea what they are planning and how it could potentially affect you. This can be problematic, especially as the margins between success and failure can be so small, but also removes some of the interaction as you are no longer interested in other players turns until they hit you with something that causes your economy to crumble.

Furthermore, there is also the issue that as there are is not a set number of turns - there are no ages and therefore no progression in what cards are available and when. This means that you may be dealt a hand of late game cards early on, which are effectively useless, or early game cards at the end when all you want to do is add VPs to your tableau, both of which can be very frustrating. Going back to Spartacus, which often is criticised for the blind drawing of cards during the intrigue phase, this offsets these issues by allowing you to sell the cards as you get them, with a reward that is roughly equivalent to the cards usefulness, meaning that if you have cards that you cannot or do not want to use, you can sell them immediately for a sizeable reward in coins which you will be able to use on a later phase. In Terraforming Mars, if you are dealt cards that are of no use, then tough luck, you just discard them for nothing and the actions that are available to you on the following turn are now far more limited.

A way to get around this somewhat is by using the card drafting variant, as described in the back of the rule book, which leads me on to …

Issue 4

Playtime. This game is not quick, despite being relatively simple. Our first play with 3 of us clocked in at around 2 hours 45 minutes, which is quite a chunk of time. As a point of reference it took us longer to play Terraforming Mars with 3 then it did to play Mage Knight the week prior with 3. The drafting method, which follows standard drafting rules and is implemented between rounds when you received the 4 random cards, further adds to this play time. Furthermore, I’m not sure how suited this game is to drafting, as all of the cards are so random, or situational, or unique that you can really plan or create combinations as you don’t know if you will ever get the other cards required in a later draft, if at all, to make your engine work, or if a really situation card will ever be relevant. The best drafting games work because there is a small subset of car types, but variations within each set. For example, within Blood Rage (or 7 Wonders) there are combat cards, clan upgrades, monsters and quests. You know roughly what you need, what you are likely to get and what can be made to work with what. There is also a far greater margin for error and ability for the player to express themselves through the well throughout curation of cards over the draft phase. All of this is missing from the TM drafting, where you are again fumbling in the dark hoping to hit upon a winning hand.

Issue 5

I won’t spend too long on this one, but the components are a joke for a game that costs £65. The card stock is some of the thinnest I have ever seen, then player boards are the same and look like they have been designed in MS paint and the art across the game is inconsistent and poor.

In conclusion, Terraforming Mars is, in my humble opinion, an okay game, but one that mechanically just isn’t very good. It reminds me of a pop song that is at first striking, but on subsequent listens just doesn’t hold up. It is also endemic of the myopic nature of board games that this currently resides at number 4 on BGG, as it does make a great first impression, after which the masses rush to the website to rate it as the best thing ever, when in reality and upon reflection, it is anything but.

The best thing I can say about TM is that it is a good distraction hiding a poor game.

I enjoyed:
- being able to select scoring conditions
- looking at the pretty main board

I disliked:
- how terrible the component quality is (One slight movement of the table, and we're all freaking out about where our cubes were on our tracks. Why are the player boards such thin, flimsy paper? Why not put the time and money into making thick boards with indentations for cubes to lay into and prevent movement? Why is the art so inconsistent in style on all the cards? Why not put in the time and money to come up with solid, consistent art on all the cards? Why would a publisher half-work SO MUCH of the game? Why do that to your customers?)
- the kinda arbitrary placement of stuff on the map (Why can I only build this specific city only in this spot? Maybe I want it on the tile above? Or on the other side of the planet.)
- the so very repetitive nature of it all (Buy cards. Maybe use them. Move a/some cubes. Get more cubes. Repeat.)
- that for how "scientific" this game is, it's still not very realistic (Smashing a moon into the planet would wipe out pretty much everything that we have accomplished up to this point. Puppies? Warm temperature? Yeah, they're gone. Welcome to the Ice Age.)
- the engine that I'm building with the cards is just not satisfying at the end of the game ("I did it. There are cubes and tiles on the map. Huh." Just such a hollow feeling after so long a time spent looking at awful cards and rearranging my cubes because of table bumps.)
- that the game does not reward more plays because it's so ridiculously balanced (I was just two points away from the winning player, who had played this game many more times than me. This doesn't feel right at all.)
- there's not much strategy beyond "Use the cards to build your engine" (You avoid this, and you lose. The corporation you play as is just a trick to make you feel like you're playing a different game every time, but you're not.)
- that the corporations are too simple in the asymmetry that it doesn't really matter what you choose to play as
- that there were so many occasions that I actually DIDN'T want to advance the game because it would mean someone else would score something on a track, thereby prolonging the repetitive nature of the game even more (The game rewards you RESISTING playing the game. That's not right.)
- that the game drags on for far too long, and if you play the game strategically, it drags on for EVEN LONGER

Final verdict: It baffles me that people are so blind to this game's ridiculous list of problems.

Terraforming Mars is a game about… well, terraforming Mars (biggest plot twist since Snakes on a Plane). The parameters towards achieving this are raising the temperature, placing oceans and raising oxygen levels. Each player controls a corporation, which can be basic or have an asymmetric start/power. The theme is cool and it’s very well implemented.

This is a game about building an engine through playing cards, moving cubes around your player boards, placing tiles trying to maximize your points, and achieving milestones. Engine builders like this are fairly MPS, so all this game could have aspired to was being a pleasant euro and an OK game. Instead, it’s garbage. Here’s why.

1. The game takes way too long. Really, way too long. I’m not a big fan of RftG, but it did a similar thing in about 30 minutes, and that’s very good. Here, you are looking at about 2h, even more at high player counts. Besides, the fact that laying tiles gives you extra points means that everybody usually wants to scrape those extra points and finish with a high score, so more often than not people keep turtling instead of triggering the end game. And to be honest, as much as I hate it, I don’t even blame the players when they do it. This doesn’t feel like a race, so I get when people get incentivized to scrape some more points in a point salad game.

2. A lot of cards are useless. I know I’m just repeating the same complaint of every person who dislikes this game, but it’s just so painful. It wasn’t so difficult to divide cards into eras. Why would you do this? You can get cards at the beginning of the game whose requirements will not be met for ages, or you can get cards at the end of the game that can only be used when the terraforming process is at an early stage. The recommended “solution” is to do the draft, which would add more time to a game that’s already too long for what it is.

3. Multiplayer solitaire. Like most engine builders, you make one or two choices at the beginning of the game, which will script your strategy. You played a card that will give you money every time you bring the heat up? Well, guess what you’re going to be doing. For some reason, they decided it was a good idea to include a few (very few) “take that” cards, which make no sense in this type of game and don’t really make it feel interactive, they just make the rest of the table think you’re a dick who’s messing with their stuff in a game that’s purely about doing your own thing and comparing scores at the end.

4. Art and production. The art is not coherent whatsoever. There’s a mix of different styles, photographies, cartoons… an absolute mess. But that’s not a big problem. Quality is, though. I’ve played some games +20 times and they looked better than TfM right out of the box. The cubes had chipped corners from day 1. The board’s quality was so bad that it started to peel, which hasn’t happened to me ever before (or after) with any board game. The player boards were also thin cardstock and the cubes would move out of place too easily, basically ruining everything.

Yes, I’ve heard that Prelude speeds up the game, and people made 3D printed stuff to hold the cubes in the player boards, and I’m happy that fans of the game found those alternatives to improve the experience, but I don’t think I should be paying extra and buy expansions to make something playable. I would buy expansions for variety or extra content in a game I love, not to fix anything. If anything, I’d be paying quite a bit to make a game that’s a 3/10 go up to a 5 or 6, and that’s not worth my time.

This is one of the few games where I dabbled with its digital version, having played about 20 games. Whatever people like about this game goes right over my head.

-Many board games have players doing math, but at least they obfuscate it. "Is this card worth paying 3 wood and 2 stone, versus this other card worth 2 wood and 3 stone, and a slightly different benefit?" In Terraforming Mars, everything is outright arithmetic. Players are doing double-digit subtractions on most turns. "I have 34 money. This card costs me 20, minus 2 because of this other card, and I have 2 steel that I can spend as 2 money each--no, 3 money each! Then I will get a refund of 3 money because it has this other tag. If I spend 3 money now to draft this card, will I have enough money to also play this 23-cost card in my hand that I desperately want?"
-There are several resources, but they are mostly different forms of money.
-Energy turning into heat automatically during each production phase is odd, and essentially makes energy production a resource in and of itself. This feels like a rough edge that should have been smoothed out.
-It is difficult to get more cards. Drafting cards each generation helps. I would never recommend to anyone (including first-timers) to play Terraforming Mars without drafting or without using the Corporate Era cards. But it is very difficult without a Race-for-the-Galaxy Explore-style action.
-The most interesting part of the game is the beginning. Choosing your starting corporation and the cards that match, then finding a way to get something going amid the dearth of resources in the opening generations... This is what I want, but throughout the whole game, not only at the beginning. There is another game that offers me exactly such decisions: it's called Race for the Galaxy.
-There are a few peaks of interest--such as racing for milestones and fighting for awards, and the last few ticks on the global parameters--but the game is otherwise a lull after the opening excitement.
-The "take that" elements feel extremely out of place in a Euro that otherwise has no direct player interaction. I understand why those cards are there, but they stand out as incongruent.
-Terraforming Mars long and has a lot of components (what other games have generic counters in of several denominations for something other than money?), but does not create an experience which is rich enough or different enough to justify all that effort.

I've read many reviews of this game, spoken to loads of people, and read books on game design, but I still don't grasp what makes Terraforming Mars an above-average game, let alone one of the highest-ranked games on BGG. I am continuously shocked by the casual gamers who not only tolerate, but enjoy a game of this scope.

That said, I totally respect that others love this game, and am not trying to detract from that. I also respect the repeat plays from the game's fans. It's hard to find games these days that people want to play dozens of times over. I only wish one such fan could cogently explain to me why!

Thankfully, Terraforming Mars: Ares Expedition streamlines the board game, focusing on the hand management aspect I enjoy, and doing away with the spatial element of the game board. Ares Expedition lives in the shadow of Race for the Galaxy, but Ares is considerably easier to teach to new players.

Played once in person and 5 or 6 more times online over Tabletop Simulator and the app version. Legitimately can't see what all the fuss is about and think the game is overhyped. Some of the things I really disliked about Terraforming Mars:

• The game is too dependent on luck-of-the-draw cards. The drafting variant only partially fixes this at the expense of extending an already over-long game.

• The Standard Actions or whatever they were called are not cost effective and therefore pretty pointless and the rewards section of the board helps rich players which is another problem; the rich get richer in this game as money is tied to victory points.

• Card cost and window of opportunity to play many of them is punishing. The deck should have been split for early game and late game options which would have helped the theme more.

• The game is just too damn long for what it is and it's pretty ugly as well with wildly inconsistent art styles. Downtime can be very high with some players having to pass again and again while others just keep on going.

• The game has a “rich get richer” problem with no suitable catch up mechanic and things cost more on the board if you're the second or third person to go for them, further compounding this problem.

• The game is nowhere near as “thematic” as people claim with some cards making zero sense in the early phase of terraforming a planet (Pets or a Sports Complex for instance!)

• The game is basically “multiplayer solitaire” with very little player interaction compared with other similar Eurogames. "Take that" cards don't count, sorry!

• The game attempts to give the impression of a variety of strategies but ultimately fails in this as you need certain card types to mesh with your chosen corporation and sometimes it just doesn't work out and creates imbalances.

I want to like this game as much as the folks I've played it with do, and I appreciate that there seems to be a lot of replayability and complexity to it. But while I originally gave this a 7 rating, I decided to downgrade the rating to reflect the reality of my reaction to it when it gets proposed in my group: meh. It's just not what I want to play.

First, it's a little too much group-solitaire for me, with the few direct player interactions (primarily asteroids) being too jarring, consequential, and unbalanced.

But the main problem for me is the incredible complexity of everybody's engine. By mid-game the engines are all pretty complex, often involving a lot of cards, and taking up so much mental energy that it's hard to have a full-game strategy that is reacting to other players. I appreciate that there are a lot of different engine styles, and that you have to build your engine with the cards you get (and be flexible and adept at doing so), but that also means that other people's engines can be very hard to understand and monitor. At a certain point I kind of give up watching the other players; I'm not familiar with all of their cards or how they work and so I just have to accept what they're doing. I don't mind having to trust that my opponents are playing their cards correctly, but I do mind that they have to trust me to do so! It's almost too much pressure and takes away some of the fun of playing a multi-player game; I like folks commenting on each other's plays and strategies, but here they are so complex and unique that that happens less frequently than other games.

Ultimately, the last few times I've seen TM session on another table at the mid-point or later, with everybody having a ton of cards in front of them, moving their bits around and talking through their engine actions, I've breathed a huge sigh of relief that I'm not playing. I'm sure I'll play it again, but I doubt it will be my first pick, knowing that I'll probably end up being fodder to folks that can handle these complex engines better than me. There are worse ways to spend an evening, however, and there are plenty of fun/interesting aspects of the game, so for now 6 it is.

A pretty unremarkable card-based tableau builder that has somehow wormed its way to the top of the charts.

A big chunk of the deck and most of the standard projects do nothing more than nudge a cube up a track to increase passive income or push the game timer. Engine building effects (aside from income increases) and emergent combos are vanishingly rare; there is very little sense of growing complexity aside from having a bit more money to throw around in the later turns, which feels like a waste when cards can offer such rich variability.

TM also breaks my one rule with card-based games like this: players need to draw cards. Lots of them. Without draw power, players are at the mercy of variance and have very little control of their fate, and TM has some of the weakest draw power I've ever seen. Players get a pitiful drip feed of cards (that they have to pay to even add to their hand!) that may have stringent requirements to play and cannot be meaningfully used to facilitate other actions ala Race for the Galaxy's economy. The beginning of each generation is usually a tiring exercise of turning down a tiny pool of obviously useless cards and wishing you could draw three times as many so you could actually make a meaningful decision with what to buy. There are even games where some players are implicitly disqualified from competing because they never see any of the condition-less income boosters (which are desperately needed early game) hidden in the massive deck. It's rare, but not rare enough for a game of this length.

Fans will say that the drafting variant helps solve all this by increasing the number of cards you see per game, but relying on an advanced variant that slows the game down to a crawl to only somewhat fix a central issue feels super lame. Just let me draw more cards dammit.

And despite there being a "map", spatial player interaction is almost nonexistent, and the board state has no meaningful connection to the card tableaus aside from some cursory special tile placements. The board mostly feels like a big VP tracker and could have easily been abstracted away to the three primary timer tracks.

Even the interesting theme has been corporatized into depressing staleness. There are older and newer games in this genre that look better, play better, and cost less. Seventy bucks for TM on the BGG shop is insane.

However, the game is a point salad; by the end you'll rack up 100+ points out of a smattering of disconnected 1-2 point choices, and a couple 5-8 point big hitters. Most turns have very little implications for what you'll be able to do more than 4 turns in the future. There's little snowballing or developing any kind of coherent strategy, just grabbing up what's generally possible in the moment. So you usually won't find any benefit in planning far ahead, nor in trying to block other players, since there's always a ton of ways to earn points and you're never honed in on any angle in particular. In this game, players get a hand of unique cards, and then on their turn they chose to take 1 or 2 actions, which could be playing a card, using a previously played ongoing effect card, or paying some number of accumulated resources to bump a marker up one of the charts on the central board. Each time you improve a chart, you get a victory point.

The game has a lot of luck in terms of which cards you wind up getting, and a lot of downtime between turns as players ponder which of their many many cards to activate. There are few, but never the less frustrating take that cards, which have very minor benefits for the player who plays them. They feel out of place in a game that's otherwise a victory points race. Another aspect of this game that I don't enjoy is that this is one of those games where as charts cap out and the game progresses, there's less and less to do with your engine. I tend to enjoy games that start out with few options, and you grow from there. On the central board, you have a hex map where you can place your plants and cities, but most of these spaces are empty, and there's apparently very little reason to place in one spot vs another spot, contributing to what's ultimately a very bland experience.

The component quality isn't great. Everything looks very bland, which isn't a deal-breaker, but the art of the cards is incredibly uneven in quality, which does bother me a bit. In a better overall game this would be forgivable. There are many games like this, where players wind up with just a huge mess of cards in their tableaus and I don't see why I would ever chose this over any of the others.

TM is one of those games I thought I'd love, being the engine-building fanboy that I am, but I came away with conflicted thoughts, rather than a ringing endorsement.

First, the positives: TM does a phenomenal job of highlighting the science and process behind the theoretical process of terraforming, while also creating a game that has many different card combinations and interactions for players to discover. These two concepts combine to give players a real sense of growth, as their corporations grow to be quite substantial and complex (seriously, there's so many cards on the table by the end of a game). These are aspects of the game I appreciate and feel are worth noting.

The negatives, however, really pull this game down for me. To start, I know it's been mentioned at length, but the component quality (particularly player boards) and artwork are substantially underwhelming and inconsistent, which makes the game feel far less engaging than it could be in the hands of a publisher known for their aesthetics. These complaints aside, the biggest issue I have with TM is that it's a game that it substantially bloated and lacks the polish I'd expect from a game of this renown. Certainly, the game provides players a series of decisions surrounding opportunity costs and strategic goals, but the high degree of variance among the cards can lead to a less-than stable game, leading to more tactical adaptations than strategic planning, which hurts in a game that is also so incredibly long for what it is (a reasonably-solitaire, optimization Euro). The introduction of multiple resources also seems interesting, but these really just operate as multiple currencies, changing the valuation of certain cards, but not really forcing players to think about these resources in dramatically different ways. This feeling of "blandness" is further experienced when one realizes that so much of the game is waiting for one's turn to finish out the strategy that they planned during the draft and that is forced by the activation of the many cards in their engine, which they must do each round in order to reap the benefits. All of this combines to create a game that while interesting, just leaves me wishing I'd played a crunchier engine-builder in a shorter amount of time (see: Race for the Galaxy, Ginkgopolis, etc - both of which provide just as, if not more, interesting decisions in 1/2 or 1/8 the time).

TM is not a bad game, but it's a bloated, messy one that seems to have gained popularity for its relative accessibility and timing of release. A game I'd play every once and a while (but only with very, very experienced players who play FAST), but not one I feel the need to run back to.

I came into the game expecting deep strategy and thoughtful planning, but after several plays, I found it quite underwhelming. It presents itself as a complex eurogame, but in reality, it’s a linear engine-builder with minimal interaction and a high reliance on luck.

Each round you get four cards and mostly just play what you’re dealt — there's little room for long-term planning. Corporations often push you toward specific card types, which might never appear. Mechanisms like collecting animals or microbes feel like decorative extras with no real impact. Even the Mars map offers very little tension — if someone takes a spot you wanted, it rarely matters.

One redeeming element is the presence of a few aggressive/sabotage cards, which at least bring some interaction — though I wish they were more central to the game.

Interestingly, a game like Isle of Cats, often labelled as a "family game" due to its theme, actually delivers a more thoughtful and tactical experience — with real planning, timing battles, and meaningful spatial decisions. Terraforming Mars, by contrast, gives the illusion of strategy without real control.

1) Terraform Mars as a mega-corporation.
2) A card-based engine-builder with a decent dose of interaction via spatial board play, races to fulfill common objectives, and a player-controlled endgame timer.
3) What I loved: The app is excellent as a game takes an hour, tops, the card-based engine building, especially with drafting, offers a nice rush of dopamine in the later stages. Mostly, I loved the fact that this is not an MPS affair - while the board play is relatively simple, it does offer interesting choices and tradeoffs, and allows you to capitalize on opportunities generated by your opponents. Finally, the end-of-game timer also offers a lot of options for interaction in non-obvious ways. For example, if oceans and oxygen are maxed out and you are interested in slowing down the pace of the game, you can fund the Thermalist award, even if you have no chance of winning it at that moment. This presents your opponents with a choice - conserve heat, thus slowing down the end of the game by not raising the temperature on Mars, or ignore the award, letting you catch up in heat and possibly take it. What your opponents are doing matters - if you see an opponent gearing up for an animal strategy, you can try maxing out temperature before oxygen, so that when oxygen is maxed out, they won't have time to capitalize on their animals. It is a good game.
4) Could be improved: A slog to get through face-to-face, and I am not sure it deserves the time investment. If Ares Expedition significantly simplified the card-play and kept the board play, it would have been an improvement.
5) First time I played this, I enjoyed it and was able to come up with a decent strategy, almost completely ignoring the board. I did not win. The game also took us 4 hours, so I didn't feel the quality of the interaction and the choices justified that. So I rated it a 6. Now I play it often on the app - the game takes an hour at most, even with drafting. For this duration, the game is excellent, combining dopamine-inducing engine-building with agonizing choices with tense board play. As a physical product, I would rate it a 7, as an app, a 9, or maybe even a 10! I'll split the difference and call it a strong 8.

Terraforming Mars is a peculiar beast. There are so many expansions and variants making it challenging to evaluate. But first off, regardless of how you're playing Terraforming Mars, the theme is fantastic and I think largely responsible for its commercial success. There is a huge deck of unique cards with their own thematic prerequisites and effects. The thematic integration in the cards is just satisfying and makes sense. The global parameters for terraforming the planet are also a unique and thematic end game trigger.

I think another reason for Terraforming Mars's commercial success is its accessibility. You could call this a medium-heavy euro but it takes less than 10 minutes to teach, and I feel comfortable introducing it to some more casual players. Regardless of individual performance, one feels a strong sense of accomplishment and ownership with the distinguished economy they have built.

But I find context very important, and the truth is Terraforming Mars did not invent any of its mechanics. In fact, tableau and engine builders are one of the most popular types of games produced today. Being innovative isn't terribly important to my enjoyment of a game, but the point is there is a lot of competition for this particular itch.

With that in mind, I'll get into my issues with the base game. First, it is way too long with too much downtime. Second, the luck of the draw is massive. Players are trying to find cards that synergize well but the game shows you far too few cards in a huge deck for this to work. Third, it is mostly multiplayer solitaire, but the interaction they do introduce through the take-that effects comes off as lazy and annoying. Many people mention the poor production, but this doesn't particularly bother me (bad art is more entertaining sometimes).

However, fans of the game suggest some fixes. The drafting variant is supposed to fix the luck of the draw issue and introduce more player interaction. I have to admit that it helps with these issues, although I was surprised by how much I still felt screwed by card draw. Perhaps graduated decks would help the issue more. Unfortunately, drafting is a wash for me because it makes the length problem much worse. And I haven't even mentioned the corporate era variant that many fans swear by which also lengthens the game because you start with no production.

The other major fix is the Prelude expansion which aims to speed up the game. Players are given more bonuses to start with so it's generally less plodding. While the game feels better with it, I feel it only shaves off about 10 minutes so Prelude failed to fix the major length issues. The map expansion (Hellas & Elysium) is a solid expansion as the base game map (along with its awards and milestones) can be underwhelming and repetitive. I can't speak for the other expansions but they come off a bit convoluted to me.

Even with these fixes, I find Terraforming Mars mediocre. There are some cool bits so I guess I understand its highly positive status, but it's thoroughly not for me. Race for the Galaxy remains my favorite tableau builder and feels like Terraforming Mars but with a fraction of the length, cost, and luck and more interesting player interaction.

A somewhat below average engine builder which hugely baloons in playtime when you get to 4 or 5 players. A perfectly fine (if unremarkable) game in and of itself, but since I can typically play a better game twice or even multiple times in the time it takes for a single game of TM, it's rarely played.

There's potentially a very solid game inside the design of TM if it had more focus on tile placement, but with the exception of Prelude, the expansions all take it further away from that design with the addition of more off-map points engines and more bloat.

I can't, for the life of me, work out how Terraforming Mars is (at the time of writing) #3 on BGG.

Don't get me wrong, TM is an okay game, if far too long for what it is. But the acclaim and fanbase it has garnered puzzles me.

I'm guessing the theme has a lot to do with it. The setting is rather evocative, after all, and it was the first thing that drew my attention. But, then again, the game is rather themeless in practice. Despite having a map and many, many cards, each with images and flavour text, Terraforming Mars is little more than procedural. And sure, I get that it's difficult to make someone feel like they're really terraforming a planet using pieces of cardboard. But I've never even paid attention to the theme of TM as I'm playing, focusing instead on the plenitudinous symbols. In short, TM's theme is as barren as Mars itself.

What of the cards? It's often said they're the highlight ot TM. The game, after all, has tonnes of cards. And yet, the card play is just okay, and more than a bit inelegant; I really think the game could do with a paring down of some of the more boring and underpowered cards. I'm sure TM fanatics will disagree with this assessment, and they're probably right to point out that more plays will breed familiarity with the cards and thus more paths to victory. But to be honest, for me the game just isn't interesting enough to warrant such a time commitment. It's an occasional game for me, and I can't see that changing.

Terraforming Mars is a great example of the principle that often, in game development, removing the excess can lead to a much better game. TM, at least in my view, is drowning in the consequences of no one having made the tough decisions as to what should be streamlined.

When playing TM, never play without the Prelude expansion; it speeds up the otherwise lethargic early game. I'd probably recommend card-drafting too, which curbs some of the game's luck, except that it makes the game much longer. And, if I haven't already made this clear, Terraforming Mars is already way, way too long.

What of other expansions? Venus adds a whole new track that lengthens the game with no real pay off. Colonies adds interesting power-ups that are worth including (easily the second-best expansion). Turmoil, which adds a whole new and exceptionally tedious phase, is a crime against humanity and should be taken outside and burnt.

Maybe these style of games aren't my favorite-favorite (though I think they would be; though I also dislike Scythe), but I was a little disappointed with Terraforming Mars because of its high acclaim. Overall, I find it a stronger game than Scythe - the three global trackers (heat, o2 and water) are integral to play and will be moved up over time. You are in a race to terraform Mars by creating an efficient economy by way of lite deck/empire building.

I think the strongest aspect of this game is it is not too heavy for a casual gamer, despite it leveraging so many board game elements: action spaces, drafting, deck building, economy/engine building, tile placement, elements, multiple resources, etc etc etc. Despite so much going on, it is not so weighty, which is due to clever game design.

Its weakest point is it's just not very exciting. There's no ah-ha moments, no gotchas, no satisfaction in setting the cards down. It is a small and monotonous climb towards the end. There's no excitement with combat like there is in Dune Imperium or Scythe, no pride in maxing out your sheep in Agricola, no satisfaction of getting Longest Road or thrill of getting to move the Robber on a 7 in Catan.

In Terraforming Mars, you just move some economy sliders, place some cards, and put some tiles down before counting up the numbers. It is very exacting, and for a game that's so precise it doesn't feel like you have a lot of control. You draw 4 cards per round and pay $3/card. There's 7 sliders, 3 types of cards, 4 types of tiles, 3 global trackers, etc etc. There is a plethora of variables and with only seeing 4 cards/round it can feel very limiting - especially if you were to pull an even more limiting corporation.

For this reason, I would presume this game feels strongest as a relaxed solo game that gives a wide berth for plotting and planning (it does not surprise me that there is a strong solo player presence online).

While I don't have a problem with 2-3+ hour games (in fact most of my favorite games range in the 90 to 180 playtime), they need to feel satisfying / exciting in order to justify that amount of investment.

There are many resource management tableau builders that are more satisfying and often shorter than Terraforming Mars. Some examples include: Everdell, Res Arcana, 51st State Master Set, Empires of the North, Race for the Galaxy (though this is less explicit resource management), Underwater Cities (very similar, but this one has a more proper ending, in my opinion).


The game starts very slowly (a little faster with the Prelude expansion, you'll save 2-3 generations in a 2p game on average with Prelude). You're initially just trying to boost up your production to be able to play more cards / actions each generation (round).


The game starts slowly, though it can play quickly if every player thinks about their turn while others are playing. I have a couple 2 player plays at around 60-75 minutes, which I think is reasonable for what this game offers as an experience. However, some people can make this game last forever. I had a 5 hour long 5 player game (never played 5 players again after that), 4 player games rarely last under 2.5-3 hours). Especially near the end of the game, when they have a bunch of action cards to think about too. This greatly increases downtime especially at 4+ players. This game is a 3 players or less game for me, I do not believe this game is worth an investment of over 2 hours.

My biggest issue with this game is that towards the end of the game, when your engine is finally up-and-running and producing good amounts of resources, you barely get to do anything interesting. There are no interesting decisions left to be made anymore. Most terraforming parameters will be capped out and there is likely only 1-2 generations (rounds) left. These two factors together make literally around 75% of the cards you have in your hand or draw useless. Worst part is that the final 1-2 generations will take up almost half the game most of the time, because people have so many action cards they need to go through to get that 1/3 of a point. Then you'll have some people stalling, selling 1 card at a time (or using 1 action then passing) to see what other players are doing and where they're placing greeneries. This makes for a very anti-climactic end of the game where all players just spam as many cities trying to benefit off others' greeneries, since most cards are now useless and they just spend it all on cities standard projects. There's a couple cards that give some VP with a decent VP / megacredit ratio that are worth playing, but otherwise no interesting decisions, just slog through the actions. An abrupt / uninteresting ending is fine for short games. For example, I don't mind getting taken out early in King of Tokyo, as the game lasts under 20 minutes. When I play a game for 2 hours though, it feels bad if it ends on a weak note.

This problem is less prominent at 2 and 3 players, as each player will get to build more of their engine and contribute more to the terraforming (less players for the same amount of terraforming to do), but the last 1-2 rounds still always feel bad to slog through.

There are a LOT of cards, so that definitely contributes greatly to the replay ability of this game. However, there are many cards that are basically useless and I've never seen played (and I've played over 20-30 games by now), and ones that are played in every single game.

The corporations feel different enough and relatively balanced from my experience, so that's a big plus. A couple feel a little more powerful, but I've seen them lose a fair bit, so I don't mind it too much, it doesn't feel overwhelming if there is a difference in power.

I much prefer the drafting variant for this game, but it does add some play time, so many people don't want to play it. Without draft, there is a significant reliance on the luck of the draw, as card usefulness and synergy varies greatly.

I have mixed opinions on the objectives and awards. I like the concept of racing others to complete these, slowing down your engine slightly to secure them first. My main issue is that I feel like it's such a wasted opportunity for more interesting varying goals tokens each game. If they were 4-5 random tokens selected each game out of say 12-15, that would spice up the gameplay a lot in my opinion People would go for different strategies to compete for the objectives, instead of always rushing greeneries, cities or building tags. I'm not interested enough to get the Hellas & Elysium expansion boards (the objectives are still static on these boards too anyway, they're just slightly different).

The art for the cards is all over the place and so random. Some of them look like pictures, others like abstract paintings and others like cartoony drawings. There is no coherence. The board and markers are also aggressively "meh" as well (aesthetically speaking).

Lastly, this game's components are atrocious in quality, especially for the price. Paper thin player boards, poor card art, chipped cubes.

I appreciate TfM for the way it speaks to novice players. Maybe it's just the theme, maybe... something else. But I've seen or met a lot of people who were casual players at best, and so many of them were just amazed by this game. We didn't know that many games the first time we played it, but already perceived ourselves as gamers, so learning the rules wasn't that hard, but it may be for beginners. And yet, they're so eager to just have it done, they actually want to learn how to play. And all this effort pays off.

There's quite a lot of things you need to take care of in the game, and it just... works. There's a lot of types of resources, but they don't feel like several flavours of the same thing, as they're connected to different game mechanics. There's a huge deck of unique cards that often make great combos together, and they all feature a bunch of icons you may want to collect, but also some of them have special conditions, and you're quite likely to draw cards that can't yet be played... but sometimes, the card can't be played ALREADY. There's a shared map and a few types of tiles you can place on it, each with its own cost and requirements and impact on the game/further placement of tiles/end game scoring. There's a race towards a few achievements, but it's also good to specialise in something and spend some money to fund a prize you may later win, as it's worth some VPs at the end of the game... but someone may do better than you and grab the prize for themselves. Finally, there's the whole thing with terraforming the planet by increasing three stats: oxygen level (by planting trees), global temperature (by turning energy into heat and spending it to move the marker) and presence of oceans (represented by ocean tiles in a shared pile). And usually, you may make such progress some other way, by using proper cards, including single-use event cards.

It's a lot, especially for a beginner, but once you played a game or two of TfM, it's just... really easy, taking turns just comes naturally, and the most thinky part here is deciding on which new cards to keep everytime a round starts, and coming up with a right sequence in which you want to play them... if only you're rich enough to afford it. That's it. It's enough to keep the players captivated and make them want to play the game more and more.

And here's the tricky part. Constant influx of new cards is exciting, a bit too exciting. It brings so many new possibilities! But, as you're quite low on cash, especially in the first few rounds, you won't be able to play all you want and just save those cards for later... and when you draw new cards, you may want to postpone playing those expensive cards, as you've just got some nice, cheap ones...
It's just how our brains work. And it's also an easy way to may ALL of your games of TfM, not just the first few ones, take AGES to finally end. Getting a lot of cards is cool, it helps you learn what's inside the main deck, but you need to start focusing on some strategies and picking just the cards that will help you put this strategy into practice and some that will keep your economy at decent level.

It took me quite some time to learn that and I'd like to spread this message to novice players so that they won't ruin TfM for themselves as we did. I'm not saying that sticking to your strategy and focusing on bringing the game closer to the end whenever you can, and as soon as you can is the only way to enjoy TfM - but please, think twice before you add additional cards from Corporate Era variant or buy unnecessary expansions (such as "Venux Next', 'Colonies', 'Turmoil').

My conundrum: I don't think this is a very good game, but I also find it very fun. I'm not sure exactly why that is.

Main problem: it's pretty easy to just entirely ignore what other players are doing for large portions of the game, even at a decently skilled level of play. In the early game, what they do doesn't really affect you; in the endgame, there's too much to keep track of to really know where you stand in relation to other players. It's one of the more interactive games of this particular breed of Euros, but it's still full of phases where you're just disengaged from other players' turns.

Also an occasional lack of interesting decision space. Can feel too often like a game that's full of objectively best moves. I don't think this is always the case, however. The terraforming path as the endgame trigger is also a great bit of design--creating this central mechanism whereby players are constantly influencing the pace of the game and moving towards a conclusion and often questioning whether they should speed up or slow down is great. The engine building is fun, but I think that collective timer is the real heart of the game. (Obviously it's not totally original, but I think this is a good implementation of the concept)

It's still a very fun game overall, but it all feels very fuzzy and full of rounded edges, vs. some of my preferred management games that have a much greater sense of precision and balance.

Also doesn't help the balance that the game fundamentally changes a ton with each additional player: goes from massively rewarding slow play and exponential growth with two players (perhaps too much) to punishing all but the most efficient of engines at five. I get why they made most of the decisions they made, but the game has some pretty much unplayable strategies (microbes, most egregiously) along with some cards that are way too good to pass if they're available--it's hard to feel a sense of agency when a lot of the time, you're basically compelled to take one card and focus on that for the whole game.

Terraforming Mars is an incredibly well designed engine building game. The variety of expansions allows players to increase the complexity and modify the interaction to suit their preferences, but Prelude is the only one I love since it shortens the game and gives players more direction to begin.

Even the base game was very clever about giving different starting options, making the teach easier and modifying the game length. The simplest version gives all players starting production, a free opening hand of cards, and no player powers. From there, you can add corporations to vary the starting production, purchase opening cards to add some tough decisions early, and draft cards to reduce luck and increase the chance to find synergy among your cards.

The graphic design and production quality are reasonable and don't take away from the gameplay. These could have been improved, but I think the publisher made the right choice by minimizing physical weight and price instead of prioritizing components and art.

My rating would be higher if it was an objective rating of the game, but unfortunately my desire to actually play this is highly dependant on the group since it can run very long when people make slow decisions and some people have studied the cards to the point where their opinions of what is "a correct action" detract from the overall enjoyment.

2025-10-26, 9/10 @ 34 plays:

The ultimate new school euro game. The progenitor of the "here's a euro game with 100+ unique cards". Others have tried (Wingspan, Earth, SETI, etc.) but this one is still the best. You have all the "play X to get more resources which let you do Y" gameplay of the standard euros, plus the contracts/goals in form of the milestones/awards, plus the board for area control, plus the asymmetrical corporations, plus the fighting over the bonuses on the oxygen/temperature track, etc. The game has a great arc. You go from barely able to do anything, but with the potential to do anything, to having more money than you can spend per round but being focused down a certain path.

People don't like that you sometimes just don't draw into cards that match your strategy. I think that happens a lot less than people make out, and is punishment for not planning around that scenario. I also don't understand the hate for the "destroy opponents plants" cards. These are necessary to stop players just hoarding greenery until they can spam a bunch in one turn. It's a necessity for the game to work.

I've only ever played with two or three players. I like both player counts, would like to try more, but I expect it maybe go on for too long.

Why isn't it a ten out of ten? This game is a 10/10 with a few expansions, but the base game alone is not perfect. The game has a slow start. The Prelude expansion solves this, and more, as it grants initial bonuses and adds even more asymmetry. Once you've played a few times, the awards/milestones on the base map can start to feel a bit samey. The variable awards/milestones expansion makes each game significantly different, the new maps are an icing on the cake. You only need the first map expansion. Colonies makes energy more useful, adds some easier way to get resources, and adds some fighting over when to fly to colonies. Venus Next is not good and can be skipped. The Venus board is barely used in our games, and floaters are very situational. I also have Prelude 2, which is probably not necessary, as I think the prelude cards added there are unbalanced. I do not care to add Turmoil, as I think the game is now "complete" for us and has enough variability to last for years to come.

The more we play Terraforming Mars, the more we love it. It's a really fun engine-builder with a simple concept - each player runs a company and can score points in 4 ways. One of these ways - Mars’ global parameters - is limited and triggers the end of the game once all of the points are gone. How you choose to score points is up to you and there's a massive deck of cards to figure it out.

There are a few things that really put this one over the top compared to other, similar games:

+ A menu of standard projects are available for players “stuck” with cards they can’t/don't want to play. There is always something you can do to move forward, regardless of luck (though luck really helps).

+ The parameters being limited controls the length of the game at any player count. At 2, the game will take 12-16 rounds as terraforming is less frequent. At 5, there are 6-8 rounds with players scrambling to grab the points before they’re gone. This also changes the companies and strategies that work best.

+ Each company and project card feels very balanced overall. I can’t think of any throwaway cards in the deck nor any that are overpowered. Still, quite a few are extremely memorable (Deimos Down, Search for Life) so there is still that excitement of finding ones you love.

+ Milestones/Awards and the shared map provide the right amount of interaction for this type of game. Payers can’t destroy each others’ engines, but they can capitalize on mistakes, grabbing points from unprotected greenery, blocking clusters of cities, nabbing early awards to force the others to pay big money to get one, and so on.

I really appreciate the feeling that I am able to come up with my own path through the game and seeing whether it ultimately works out or not. Things will change, of course, because the cards you'll get are unknown, but by the end of the game you have created your own, unique company, and get to enjoy its success or failure. This is the piece that's missing in Ark Nova and why I like Terraforming Mars so much better.

- The most obvious gripe is the incredibly poor quality of the tokens, the artwork on the cards, and the cost of the game. I think the game itself overshadows these and no one I've played with has cared beyond a joke or two, but for those that like a premium feel when they're paying a premium price, this will definitely drop the game a peg or two (and it has impacted my score).

SOLO NOTE: I've played Terraforming Mars solo one time. I didn't care for it as instead of playing a somewhat normal game against an automated opponent, you instead simply try to complete the terraforming in a set number of rounds. This makes so many cards and strategies useless, since only the terraforming part matters; it effectively turns the game into a luck-fest where you hope to get cards that help build heat and plant production.

There is a new Automa expansion that makes the solo mode more like playing against a human, which sounds better, but I have yet to try it.

Kurzrezension:
In "Terraforming Mars" versuchen die Spieler gemeinsam den Mars bewohnbar zu machen. Es ist aber alles andere als ein kooperatives Unterfangen! Nur derjenige, der die Parameter des roten Planeten am besten beeinflusst, gewinnt am Ende die Partie.

Spielablauf:
"Terraforming Mars" ist ein Kartenspiel mit Spielplan, der im Grunde nur eine Statusanzeige darstellt.
In jeder Runde erhalten die Spieler eine Reihe von Karten, die - nach einem Draft mit den Mitspielern - auf die Kartenhand eingekauft werden können.
Wer am Zug ist, führt ein bis zwei Aktionen durch. Standardaktionen sind auf dem Spielbrett angegeben. Sie kosten eine Menge Geld, verändern die Oberfläche des Mars und erhöhen damit das eigene Einkommen, indem Grünflächen, Städte und dergleichen errichtet werden. Mit einer weiteren Standardaktion können Meilensteine und Auszeichnungen finanziert werden, die bei Spielende für denjenigen, der sie erreicht, wichtige Siegpunkte wert ist.
Hauptsächlich werden Aktionen zum Ausspielen eigener Karten genutzt. Es gibt sie in drei verschiedenen Versionen:
- Grüne Karten stellen einmalige Bonnies zur Verfügung, bleiben aber offen ausgespielt, da sich andere Karten auf ihre Symbole beziehen können.
- Blaue Karten bieten dauerhafte Effekte oder zusätzliche Aktionsmöglichkeiten pro Runde.
- Rote Karten werden nach dem Ausspielen auf den eigenen Ablagestapel abgeworfen, sind meist sehr teuer, beinhalten dafür eine große Ausbeute.
Im Spiel werden sechs verschiedene Ressourcen verwaltet, von denen jede mit einem Einkommensmarker nachgehalten wird, die am Rundenende automatisch Ressourcen generieren. Geld, Stahl und Titan werden überwiegend für das Ausspielen von Karten genutzt, kann aber auch an anderer Stelle Verwendung finden. Mit acht Pflanzen können Parks auf dem Mars erschaffen, um damit den CO₂-Gehalt zu erhöhen. Energie ist zum Betreiben von Karteneffekten und für den Städtebau wichtig. Nicht genutzter Strom wird am Ende der Runde in Wärme umgewandelt und diese dient schlussendlich dazu, den Mars zu erwärmen!
Immer wenn einer der drei globalen Parameter (Ozeanfläche, Temperatur oder CO₂-Gehalt) erhöht wird, steigt der Terraformwert des auslösenden Spielers. Dieser ist für das Geldeinkommen jeder Runde wichtig und stellt gleichzeitig den Siegpunktmarker dar.
Am Ende jeder Runde erhalten die Spieler Einkommen für alle sechs Ressourcentypen. Außerdem werden alle Marker von den blauen Aktionskarten genommen, bevor eine neue Runde beginnt.
Das Spiel endet nach der Runde, in der alle drei globalen Parameter ihr Maximum erreicht haben.
Wer dann die meisten Punkte aus Terraformwert, Meilensteine und Auszeichnungen, sowie den Punkten auf manchen Karten hat, gewinnt die Partie.

Erweiterung:
Die erste erschienene Erweiterung "Hellas & Elysium" ist ein neuer Spielplan mit neuen Meilensteinen und Herausforderungen. Durch die beiden neuen Oberflächen des Mars ändert sich auch das Terraformen des roten Planeten, was zu einer etwas anderen Herangehensweise führt. Vor allem sind es aber die Meilensteine und Herausforderungen, die diese Erweiterung lohnenswert macht.

In "Nächster Halt Venus", der zweiten Erweiterung des Erfolgshits, müssen sich die Spieler zusätzlich um die Belange eines weiteren Himmelskörpers kümmern. Die Venus soll so umgewandelt werden, dass ein Leben auf schwebenden Stationen der Atmosphäre möglich ist. Dazu liegen der Erweiterung neue Projektkarten und ein neuer Spielplan - der die Venus und deren globalen Parameter zeigt - bei.
Für meinen Geschmack fügt diese Erweiterung etwas zu viel Spielzeit hinzu, ohne den Spielern einen Mehrwert zu bieten. Ich spiele mit ihr dennoch von Zeit zu Zeit ganz gerne.

Die "Preludium" bzw. "Preludium 2"-Erweiterungen bestehen hauptsächlich aus den namensgebenden "Prelude"-Karten, von denen jeder Spieler mit zwei aus vier Karten ins Spiel startet. Diese Karten erhöhen diverse Einkommen und sorgen für einen Grundstock an Symbolen und überspringen damit quasi die erste Spielrunde des Grundspiels.
Von all den Erweiterungen kann ich "Prelude" uneingeschränkt empfehlen. Der langsame Aufbau, den die ersten paar Spielrunden des Grundspiels bestimmt hat, hat mit dieser Erweiterung ein Ende. Sie wirft die Spieler direkt ins Geschehen und beschleunigt das Spiel ungemein, ohne den Spielspaß zu trüben.
Für mich ein Muss für jeden TFM-Fan.

Die vierte Erweiterung "Kolonien" fügt mit weiteren Projektkarten eine neue Mechanik ins Spiel ein, mit der es möglich ist, Kolonien zu gründen. Dazu stehen verschiedene Plättchen bereit, auf dem die Raumschiffe der Spieler platziert werden können, um diverse Sondereigenschaften zur Verfügung zu stellen.
Auch diese Erweiterung mag ich sehr. Sie vergrößert zwar etwas die Menge an Regeln, bietet aber auch eine weitere thematische Möglichkeit an Punkte zu kommen.
Ich mag die Kolonien sehr, oftmals können sie aber aufgrund von Neulingen am Tisch nicht mitspielen, was sehr schade ist.

Eine enorme Menge an Regeln bringt die "Aufruhr" Erweiterung mit. Sie kümmert sich um die politischen Belange der 'Erde' und des 'Mars'. Die Spieler können 'Politiker' in den Rat setzen, was Aktionen und Geld kostet. Dafür dürfen sie mitbestimmen, welche Regeln die Kolonialisierung des roten Planeten beeinflussen sollen.
"Aufruhr" ist eine geniale Erweiterung, da sie dem Grundspiel eine weitere Möglichkeit hinzufügt, sich im Spiel zu entwickeln. Außerdem erhöht sie die direkte Interaktion der Spieler auf ein noch höheres Niveau. Allerdings lasse ich diese Erweiterung oftmals weg, da es Neulinge am Tisch einfach überfordert. Schade eigentlich, denn sie ist nach "Präludium" die beste von allen.

Meinung:
"Terraforming Mars" ist ein Spiel, das öfter gespielt werden sollte, um die große Anzahl Karten und deren Effekte kennenzulernen und einschätzen zu können. Spätestens ab der zweiten Partie sollten auch die Standard-Konzerne weggepackt und mit denen des erweiterten Grundspiels gespielt werden. Zusätzlich empfehle ich dringend zur Draftvariante, bei der die Kartenauswahl wesentlich gerechter ausfällt, als beim zufälligen Ziehen vom Deck. Somit kann ich nur absolute Spielanfänger das abgespeckte Spiel empfehlen, um erst einmal ins Spiel hineinfinden zu können.
Mir gefällt "Terraforming Mars" mit jeder gespielten Partie immer mehr. Ein kleiner Wermutstropfen sind die Doppel-Layer Spielertableaus, welche in anderen Spielen selbstverständlich enthalten sind, für dieses Spiel aber teuer nachgekauft werden müssen. Im Grundspiel sind nur dünne Ablagetableaus enthalten, auf denen die Marker verrutschen. Bei dem Preis des Spiels eigentlich eine Frechheit!
Auch ein Insert kam erst mit einer "Big Box" hinzu. Diese enthält dafür beeindruckende 3D-modellierte Landschaftsplättchen und sorgt damit für eine tolle Tischpräsenz!
Anfangs war ich von "Terraforming Mars" nicht überzeugt. Es brauchte drei Partien, bis es mich begeistern konnte und heute bin ich froh, dass ich es damals nicht direkt verkauft hatte. In der Zwischenzeit spiele ich es auch oft digital, da die haptische Version bedauerlicherweise immer noch zu selten auf den Tisch kommt, obwohl die Spielzeit für ein Spiel dieses Kalibers durchaus angenehm kurz ist.
Ich empfinde das Spiel auch als überaus thematisch. Viele andere stören sich an den unterschiedlichen Illustrationsstil der Karten. Für mich gehört dies aber dazu, denn es arbeiten schließlich eine ganze Menge verschiedener Persönlichkeiten daran, den Mars bewohnbar zu machen und diese Menschen stellen ihre Projekte eben auf unterschiedliche Art und Weise dar.
Von den Erweiterungen habe ich alle schon gespielt und kann in erster Linie "Präludium", sowie "Präludium 2" wärmstens empfehlen. Sie beschleunigen das nur langsam in Gang kommende Spiel um ein bis zwei Runden. Wer es etwas komplexer und mehr Interaktion wünscht, der sollte sich auf jeden Fall die "Aufruhr"-Erweiterung näher anschauen. Und wer sich einfach nur etwas Abwechslung wünscht, dem sind die verschiedenen Kartenerweiterungen "Hellas und Elysium" und Co. zu empfehlen.
"Terraforming Mars" hatte es Anfangs schwer bei mir zu punkten. Mittlerweile gehört es aber zu meinen liebsten Spielen im Regal.

A really great game just with one flaw making it inperfect.
Pros:
- Theme (I just love everyhting space based), and here we have a eurogame not about wars and destroying things, but the game where you try to make the world around you better (big applause for this one)
- Good and well-thought rules. It takes some time to explain the game rules, but once explained everything works just fine
- Huge replayability
- Huge tactic variaty (you can win the game in lots of ways)
- Cards design - all cards are unique and all of them are with explanation text. I.e. all corporations are with background, all projects are also explained in game lore. Thats huge amount of work!
- I love player interaction.

But unfortunately there are cons.
Major one:
- Horrible component quality. The game board is worn out after 2 games. Very bad player mats, money cobes which became damaged after one playthrough, game cards are also cheaply made. Even the game box if thin and poorly assembled.
I wouldn't thought that I'd ever consider a component quality as a major flaw, but here it is.

And minor flaws:
- A lot of useless cards at the end of the game. Splitting cards into 3 eras would be a great idea
- The game is somewhat long. If you have a person, who never played the game or at least one person with AP (analysis paralysis), the game session could last more than 3 hours. It takes for 2 experienced players to finish the game in 1.5 hours.
